The Alliance enslaved the Terrans after overthrowing the Terran Empire, and was co-ruled by the Klingon Empire and Cardassian Union. By the early 2370s (DS9 \"Crossover\" era), Terrans had formed a resistance against the Alliance's oppression. The Alliance is essentially the oppressive flip side of the mirror Klingon and Cardassian regimes, united by a mutual desire to dominate former Terran territories."       },       {         "name": "Vulcans",         "keys": ["Vulcan", "Vulcans"],         "category": "Species",         "content": "Vulcans are a humanoid species from the planet Vulcan. They are physically similar to humans but distinguished by pointed ears and upswept eyebrowsÓ®Å46Ó®Ç and copper-based green blood. Vulcans are renowned for their devotion to logic and the suppression of emotionsÓ®Å47Ó®Ç, following the teachings of Surak (who led the Great Awakening on Vulcan 2,000 years ago). They possess telepathic abilities (e.g., the mind meld) and have lifespans of about 200 years. Vulcans were founding members of the Federation in 2161. Their culture values IDIC (Infinite Diversity in Infinite Combinations) and practices like kolinahr (purging all remaining emotion). Though outwardly stoic, Vulcans do experience deep emotions but control them with strict mental discipline. Every seven years, adult Vulcans undergo pon farr (a mating cycle that compels them to mate or die). Ancient Vulcans were warlike, but modern Vulcans prize peace and logic above all."       },       {         "name": "Bajorans",         "keys": ["Bajoran", "Bajorans"],         "category": "Species",         "content": "The Bajorans are a humanoid species native to the planet Bajor in the Alpha Quadrant. The Bajorans have one of the oldest civilizations, with a rich culture spanning tens of thousands of yearsÓ®Å48Ó®Ç. Physically, they resemble humans except for a series of horizontal nose ridges. Bajorans are deeply spiritual ‚Äì their religion centers on the Prophets (benevolent aliens residing in the Bajoran Wormhole) whom they regard as gods. Many Bajorans wear an elaborate earring (d'ja pagh) on the right ear as a symbol of their faithÓ®Å49Ó®Ç. Bajor was occupied by the Cardassian Union from 2319 to 2369, during which Bajorans formed a fierce Resistance that fought a guerrilla war. After liberation, Bajor established a provisional government and considered Federation membership (delayed until after the Dominion War). Bajoran society is led by a spiritual leader (the Kai) and a secular government (the Chamber of Ministers). They value family, artistic expression, and faith; their culture is known for its art, architecture, and philosophy of pagh (spirit). Bajorans continue to rebuild their world following the occupation, guided by their enduring faith and cultural heritage."       },       {         "name": "Andorians",         "keys": ["Andorian", "Andorians"],         "category": "Species",         "content": "Andorians are a blue-skinned humanoid species from Andoria (a moon of a gas giant), and founding members of the Federation. They are distinguished by a pair of movable cranial antennaeÓ®Å50Ó®Ç and white or silver hair. Andorians are passionate, proud, and tend toward a militaristic, honor-based culture. They evolved from subterranean ice dwellers, and their antennae aid in balance and low-light navigationÓ®Å51Ó®Ç. Andorian society in the 22nd century was led by the Imperial Guard and a feudal nobility (e.g., the Andorian Emperor). They had a history of conflict (and later alliance) with Vulcans. Andorians are known to be argumentative and blunt. They form strong family bonds (including four genders in their reproductive cycle, per Enterprise novels). Their subspecies, the telepathic Aenar (an albino, blind offshoot), also live on Andoria. Andorians served with distinction in Starfleet (e.g., Commander Shran assisted Captain Archer). They value honor and loyalty, making them fierce warriors and steadfast allies."       },``````json       {         "name": "Tellarites",         "keys": ["Tellarite", "Tellarites"],         "category": "Species",         "content": "Tellarites are a stout, porcine-featured humanoid species from Tellar PrimeÓ®Å52Ó®Ç. They have snout-like noses (often likened to pig-like features) and sometimes tusk-like teeth. Culturally, Tellarites are known for being argumentative and blunt ‚Äì they consider heated debate and constant complaining as normal social interaction (a Tellarite greeting often involves good-natured insults). They possess keen hearing and smellÓ®Å53Ó®Ç. Tellarites were founding members of the Federation, contributing their engineering and technical expertise. In the 22nd century, they were involved in key diplomatic conferences (e.g., the Babel Conference in 2150s). Physically, their skin tones range pink to brown, and they have hoof-like feet (in some depictions). While gruff and sometimes obstinate, Tellarites value honesty and have a strong sense of practicality, making them excellent engineers and politicians (as they will argue every point vigorously)."       },       {         "name": "Betazoids",         "keys": ["Betazoid", "Betazoids"],         "category": "Species",         "content": "Betazoids are a telepathic and empathic humanoid species from the planet Betazed. Externally, Betazoids look nearly identical to humans except for their eyes ‚Äì Betazoid irises are completely blackÓ®Å54Ó®Ç. Betazoids develop their telepathic abilities typically in adolescence; by adulthood most are full telepaths (able to sense thoughts and emotions). They value honesty and openness (some say because they cannot hide truths telepathically). Betazed society is generally peaceful and highly artistic. They were Federation members by the 24th century. During the Dominion War, Betazed was occupied by the Dominion for a time (a great shock due to Betazed‚Äôs traditionally undefended status). Notable Betazoids include Counselor Deanna Troi and Ambassador Lwaxana Troi. Betazoids‚Äô empathic bond with others make them sought after as counselors and diplomats. Culturally, they celebrate a open sexuality and frankness (e.g., traditional Betazoid weddings are conducted in the nude to symbolize honesty)."       },       {         "name": "Trill (Joined)",         "keys": ["Trill", "Joined Trill"],         "category": "Species",         "content": "The Trill are a humanoid species from the planet Trill (in the Alpha Quadrant) known for a unique symbiotic tradition: some Trill host a long-lived symbiont. Joined Trill carry an internal symbiont slug in their abdomen, forming a permanent bond. The symbiont shares memories with the host, and upon a host‚Äôs death is transplanted to a new host ‚Äì thus a joined Trill has the experiences of multiple lifetimes. Externally, Trill hosts have a line of brown-black spots running down each side of their body. Only a small percentage of Trill qualify to be hosts after a rigorous selection process (the Symbiosis Commission oversees this). The symbionts live for centuries. Example: Jadzia Dax (DS9) was the 8th host of the Dax symbiont. Unjoined Trill live ordinary lives and typically do not know symbiont memories. The Joined Trill culture emphasizes protecting the symbiont and using its wisdom for the betterment of society. Trill society is advanced and peaceful, a Federation member by the late 24th century. Trills in TNG had a slightly different depiction (with forehead ridges), later refined to the spotted look. A joined Trill can access previous hosts‚Äô skills (e.g., Jadzia could play music known by a prior host, Curzon). The rule is that hosts should not contact people from previous lives (to avoid emotional complications). The Trill concept explores identity ‚Äì each joined individual is a blend of new and old."       },       {         "name": "Gorn",         "keys": ["Gorn"],         "category": "Species",         "content": "The Gorn are a warp-capable, bipedal reptilian species from the Beta Quadrant. They have green, scaly skin and are very strong (capable of overpowering an average human easily). First encountered by the Federation in 2267 (TOS ‚ÄúArena‚Äù), the Gorn operate under the Gorn Hegemony. Gorn society is somewhat territorial and xenophobic. The Gorn move and speak slowly by human standards (in their first contact, a Gorn captain‚Äôs speech was deep and hissing). Their warships are powerful and often rely on brute force. A Gorn‚Äôs physiology includes an average height of 2+ meters and great durability; they are cold-blooded (prefer warm environments). After the initial clash at Cestus III (which the Gorn attacked believing it to be an intrusion), the Gorn entered a wary peace with the Federation. In the 24th century, Gorn aligned with the Klingon Empire at times (in the STO timeline). The Mirror Universe Gorn were enslaved by the Terran Empire until the Alliance freed them. Overall, the Gorn are formidable foes ‚Äì strong, resilient, but not very agile ‚Äì and their culture values strength and territorial control."       },       {         "name": "Tholians",         "keys": ["Tholian", "Tholians"],         "category": "Species",         "content": "Tholians are a crystalline-based non-humanoid species from Tholia in the Alpha QuadrantÓ®Å55Ó®Ç. They have a rigid crystalline exoskeleton and exist at extremely high temperatures (~480 K); their environment would instantly kill humans. Tholians communicate in a high-pitched, crystalline manner. They are extremely xenophobic and isolationistÓ®Å56Ó®Ç. The Tholian Assembly is their government, known for being precise and territorial (‚ÄúTholians are punctual‚Äù as

4.content: Spock noted). They notably can generate the \"Tholian Web,\" an energy lattice used to trap enemy vessels (seen in TOS ‚ÄúThe Tholian Web‚Äù). Tholians rarely leave their territory; when they do, they often retaliate harshly against incursions (they attacked a Federation ship in TOS and nearly captured USS Defiant in ENT via time/space rift). They are non-humanoid: reports suggest Tholians resemble faceted crystal arachnoids. Because of their unique biology, direct Federation contact is limited. The Assembly in the 24th century avoided Dominion entanglement, simply closing borders. In sum, Tholians are enigmatic, extremely defensive, and one of the few known non-biological intelligences. They prove that not all life is carbon-based."       },       {         "name": "Orions",         "keys": ["Orion", "Orions"],         "category": "Species",         "content": "Orions are a warp-capable humanoid species with green (sometimes blue-green) skin, originating from the Orion system in the Beta QuadrantÓ®Å57Ó®Ç. Culturally, Orions have a reputation as pirates, slavers, and crime lords ‚Äì epitomized by the Orion Syndicate. Orion society is often portrayed as having male-dominated hierarchies outwardly, but Orion females produce powerful pheromones that can influence males (of many species) ‚Äì leading to the revelation that Orion women often secretly pull the strings. In the 22nd century, Orion slavers operated in the Borderlands (ENT ‚ÄúBorderland‚Äù). In the 23rd, an Orion woman (Navaar) was part of the mirror Tholian plot and prime universe Orions raided multiple ships. By the 24th century, Orions integrated somewhat (an Orion serves in Starfleet in DSC era, and some joined the Ferengi Alliance). Physically, Orions are comparable to humans but tend to be robust. Orion men often bald or with black hair, women famously voluptuous. The Orion Syndicate‚Äôs reach means many Orions operate on colony worlds as smugglers or entertainers (e.g., Orion ‚Äúdancers‚Äù often appear but may actually be intelligence gatherers using pheromones). Orions value profit, similar to Ferengi but with a more violent approach if needed. In Starfleet Academy, Orions are still relatively rare. The Orions show how a species can straddle legitimate and illegitimate enterprises ‚Äì some Orions are merchants and traders, others remain very much pirates of old. Their neutral stance belies their involvement in behind-the-scenes manipulation via the Syndicate."       },       {         "name": "Xindi",         "keys": ["Xindi"],         "category": "Species",         "content": "The Xindi are a collection of sentient species from the Delphic Expanse who share a common origin. The five surviving Xindi species (after a long-ago civil war) are: Xindi-Primates (humanoid), Xindi-Arboreals (sloth-like humanoids), Xindi-Reptilians, Xindi-Insectoids, and Xindi-AquaticsÓ®Å58Ó®Ç. A sixth, the Xindi-Avian, went extinct during their internecine warsÓ®Å59Ó®Ç. Despite different physiologies, they consider each other part of one Xindi race. In the 2150s, the Xindi Council was manipulated by trans-dimensional Sphere-Builders into believing humans would destroy them. This led to the Xindi Crisis (ENT Season 3), where the Xindi built a planet-killer weapon and attacked Earth (killing 7 million in 2153) as a test. Captain Archer convinced the Xindi to turn against the Sphere-Builders and abort the attack. Culturally, each species has its traits: Primates are diplomatic/scientific, Arboreals are peaceful, Aquatics are methodical and communicate slowly, Reptilians are militant and aggressive, Insectoids are hive-minded and quick to act. After the incident, the Xindi aligned more positively with humanity; novels suggest they eventually join the Federation in the 26th century. The Xindi homeworld was destroyed during their civil war; by Archer‚Äôs time they lived on multiple colony worlds. The Xindi are notable as a case of multiple distinct species evolving on one planet (presumably due to some ancient intervention). Their cooperation in the Council (when it works) shows they can overcome biological differences. Post-2154, they returned to isolation to rebuild, but maintained some contact via Ambassador (Degra‚Äôs legacy)."       },       {         "name": "Hirogen",         "keys": ["Hirogen"],         "category": "Species",         "content": "The Hirogen are a nomadic humanoid species of the Delta Quadrant known as fearsome hunters. They are tall (often over 2 meters) and physically powerful, wearing heavy armor suits. Hirogen society lacks a homeworld ‚Äì instead, they roam in packs across vast regions of space in search of preyÓ®Å60Ó®Ç. Their culture is entirely centered on The Hunt; Hirogen live to stalk and kill worthy prey, collecting trophies (skulls, etc.). Each Hirogen hunting group is led by an ‚ÄúAlpha‚Äù (pack leader)Ó®Å61Ó®Ç. They communicate minimally ‚Äì focusing on tracking tactics. Their technology includes advanced weaponry (polaron rifles, spread mines) and ships with powerful sensors (to find prey). Voyager encountered the Hirogen multiple times, culminating in a deal where Janeway gave them holodeck technology to simulate hunts (in hopes of curbing their nomadic bloodlust). The Hirogen have no qualms hunting intelligent species (they attempted to hunt Voyager‚Äôs crew). Socially, they seem to have had an ancient civilization that fell apart because their obsession with hunting prevented other development. The post-Voyager holographic technology situation (as per ‚ÄúFlesh and Blood‚Äù) led to some Hirogen being killed by their holographic prey, hinting at possible cultural shifts. Nonetheless, as of late 24th century, the Hirogen remain a cautionary tale of a society consumed by violent purpose. Their motto might as well be ‚ÄúWhat you hunt, you honor by killing‚Äù. They rarely form alliances (the Dominion had no known contact; Hirogen operate alone). Physiology note: they can subsist on raw meat of prey; they have redundant organs (hard to kill). In summary, the Hirogen are ‚Äúspace apex predators,‚Äù a unique and dangerous culture of hunters."       },       {         "name": "Kazon",         "keys": ["Kazon"],         "category": "Species",         "content": "The Kazon are a nomadic, aggressive humanoid species in the Delta Quadrant, featured in Star Trek: Voyager‚Äôs early seasons. Physically, Kazon have distinctive crest-like dreadlock hair and ridged foreheads. Culturally, they are divided into sects (18 major sects as of 2372) that constantly vie for resources and powerÓ®Å62Ó®Ç. The Kazon used to be enslaved by the Trabe, an advanced species. In 2346, the Kazon rebelled and overthrew the Trabe (earning freedom but inheriting only the Trabe‚Äôs outdated technology)Ó®Å63Ó®Ç. Kazon sects like the Nistrim, Ogla, Relora, etc., each control different territories and rarely cooperate. They lack replicators, transporter tech, or sophisticated warp drives (Voyager was far more advanced). Kazon society values strength and brutality; they often engage in piracy (stealing water, technology). A sect leader is called a Maje. Women seem to have subordinate status (no female Majes seen). Voyager‚Äôs presence sparked a power struggle ‚Äì e.g., Culluh of the Nistrim allied with the disgraced Cardassian Seska to try to capture Voyager. They briefly succeeded (Voyager was taken in ‚ÄúBasics‚Äù) but lost it due to internal betrayal and Voyager‚Äôs crew retaking the ship. The Kazon, due to infighting and limited tech, were considered not a serious threat by the Borg (who deemed them unworthy of assimilation). After Voyager left their space, little is known ‚Äì presumably sects kept battling. The Kazon illustrate a post-enslavement society that fell into factional violence. They are analogous to street gangs fighting over scraps of the Trabe‚Äôs legacy. Some humanitarian Federation attempts (Chakotay once gave the Ogla water) did not change the status quo. In short, the Kazon are combative, divided, and technologically behind ‚Äì a danger in numbers but not unified enough to be more than a regional menace."       },       {         "name": "Vidiians",         "keys": ["Vidiian", "Vidiians"],         "category": "Species",         "content": "The Vidiians were a species found in the Delta Quadrant. For two millennia, the entire race suffered from a disease called the Phage that ate skin and internal organs, killing thousands dailyÓ®Å64Ó®Ç. To survive, the Vidiians turned to harvesting organs and body parts from other species to replace their diseased tissue. They became unparalleled experts in medical science ‚Äì capable of transplanting organs within minutes and using weapons that can extract organs. A Vidiian's appearance is often ghastly: patchwork skin grafts from various donors covering lesions. Morally, many Vidiians hated what the Phage forced them to do, but saw no choice. When Voyager encountered them, they stole Neelix‚Äôs lungs (but returned them after harvesting a replacement from Kes‚Äôs tissue) and split B'Elanna Torres into two (Klingon/human) to cure the disease. The Phage was highly adaptive and incurable for centuries. By late 2370s (as hinted in VOY ‚ÄúThink Tank‚Äù), a cure was eventually found, freeing the Vidiians from their nightmare. Pre-Phage, Vidiian society was described as artistic and culturally rich. During the Phage years, they formed the Vidiian Sodality (their government) which prioritized finding a cure at any cost. After a cure, it's hoped the Vidiians would cease organ-harvesting and rebuild their civilization. The Vidiians stand as one of Voyager‚Äôs most tragic adversaries ‚Äì not evil, but driven to terrible acts by desperation. Their legacy also gave Federation medical science a boost (The Doctor learned advanced organ grafting techniques from studying Vidiian research)."       },       {         "name": "Founders (Changelings)",         "keys": ["Founder", "Founders", "Changelings"],         "category": "Species",         "content": "The Founders (Changelings) are a shape-shifting gelatinous species native to the Gamma Quadrant.

5.content: They are the architects and rulers of the Dominion, revered by the Dominion's inhabitants as gods. In their natural state, Changelings exist as viscous amber liquid and can merge together in the Great Link ‚Äì a collective sea where they share thoughts and feelings. Individually, a Changeling can assume virtually any form (living or inanimate) by reconfiguring its mass. They typically revert to liquid state to regenerate every 16 hours or so. The Founders were once persecuted by solids, which drove them to impose order (the Dominion) to ensure their safety. They show little regard for ‚Äúsolid‚Äù life, using the Dominion to control and, if necessary, exterminate threats. Odo (from DS9) is a notable Changeling who was raised by solids and taught the Founders a lesson in ‚Äúsolids can be trusted.‚Äù Physically, when at rest, Founders in humanoid form often appear with smooth, featureless faces (due to imperfect mimicry). They are virtually immortal (as long as they revert to liquid to heal injuries) and can tolerate extreme conditions. The only known weaknesses: a morphogenic virus (created by Section 31) nearly wiped them out in the late 2370s, and certain technobabble solutions (e.g., quantum stasis field) can trap them mid-shift. The Founders inhabit a planet in the Omarion Nebula (at least until 2371 when a joint Tal Shiar/Obsidian Order fleet attacked it ‚Äì which was a trap that killed the invaders). After Odo cured the Founders‚Äô virus in 2376 and joined the Great Link, it‚Äôs suggested the Dominion became less aggressive. The Founders represent the ultimate ‚Äúoutsiders‚Äù ‚Äì utterly different lifeforms who sought to reshape the galaxy out of fear, and in doing so, became feared and hated by many."       },       {         "name": "Vorta",         "keys": ["Vorta"],         "category": "Species",         "content": "The Vorta are a humanoid species genetically engineered by the Founders to serve as the Dominion's administrators, diplomats, and strategists. According to legend (as told by a Vorta), the Founders uplifted the primitive Vorta after a family of Vorta hid a Changeling from attackers ‚Äì thus the Founders rewarded them with intelligence and purpose. Modern Vorta are cloned; each time one dies, the Founders can activate a clone replacement (with memory updates if available). Vorta typically have pale or grayish skin, elongated ears, and purple eyes. They possess certain enhancements: limited telekinesis (some sources), acute hearing, and most notably an immunity to most poisons (they can even detect poison by taste)Ó®Å65Ó®Ç. Culturally, Vorta are programmed to revere Founders as gods ‚Äì they will commit suicide rather than betray a Founder. They are masters of obsequious diplomacy (Weyoun exemplifies their polite, ingratiating manner). While not physically imposing, they command Jem'Hadar forces and handle Dominion political affairs. Vorta have a very poor aesthetic sense ‚Äì they find beauty in things other species do not (an anecdote: Weyoun admitted Vorta cannot appreciate art or music, possibly engineered out). Notable Vorta include Weyoun (there were at least 8 clones of him), Kilana, Keevan, and Damar‚Äôs Vorta advisor Luaran. The Vorta handle all the ‚Äúdirty work‚Äù of running an empire ‚Äì espionage, negotiation, logistics ‚Äì under the Founders‚Äô direction, freeing the god-like Changelings to remain distant. In DS9, one Weyoun defected due to a glitch (Weyoun 6), showing that Vorta loyalty, while strong, is not infallible. But in general, the Vorta are content to be the Dominion‚Äôs calculating middle managers, trading freedom for power granted by their deities."       },       {         "name": "Jem'Hadar",         "keys": ["Jem'Hadar"],         "category": "Species",         "content": "The Jem'Hadar are the genetically engineered shock troops of the Dominion. Bred in birthing hatcheries, they reach maturity in just a few days and are engineered for combat ‚Äì they do not need sleep, food, or recreation, only a life-sustaining drug called Ketracel-WhiteÓ®Å66Ó®ÇÓ®Å67Ó®Ç. White contains an enzyme the Jem'Hadar lack; without it, they go into withdrawal and die, ensuring their dependency and obedience. Jem'Hadar are reptilian-humanoids, often gray-skinned and physically imposing (stronger than humans, with some personal shrouding cloaking ability that renders them invisibleÓ®Å68Ó®Ç). Their lifespan is short (few years, if that, assuming they aren‚Äôt killed in battle). They ‚Äúlive to fight‚Äù and follow the mantra ‚ÄúVictory is Life.‚Äù Their loyalty to the Founders is absolute (ingrained via conditioning: they salute with ‚ÄúWe pledge our loyalty to the Founders, from now until death‚ÄùÓ®Å69Ó®Ç). Hierarchy among Jem'Hadar is based on age: the oldest is the First, who commands; second-oldest is Second, etc.Ó®Å70Ó®Ç. They have no civilian society ‚Äì they are literally born soldiers. Some Jem'Hadar (the ‚ÄúAlpha‚Äù breed created in the Alpha Quadrant) showed slight independent streaks and conflict with the Gamma-bred Jem'Hadar, but all still served the Dominion. They utilize personal polaron rifles and wear organic armor. In battle, Jem'Hadar are fanatically fearless ‚Äì they do not surrender or retreat unless ordered. If a mission requires, they will perform suicide runs (e.g., ramming the Odyssey). Socially, they have ritualized use of White (distribution by a Vorta, often with the First reciting loyalty pledges). No Jem'Hadar has seen old age. Only one Jem'Hadar (DS9 ‚ÄúHippocratic Oath‚Äù) ever tried to break free of White and develop independence, but it failed due to ingrained nature. The Jem'Hadar are perhaps the most effective fighting force of their size in the galaxy, but also tragic ‚Äì they have no art, no family, engineered to know only war. After the Dominion War, presumably new Jem'Hadar are still bred in Gamma Quadrant to enforce order there, but their role in the Alpha Quadrant ceased. They remain a stark example of the ethical cost of Dominion‚Äôs quest for control."       },       {         "name": "NX-class Starship",         "keys": ["NX-class", "NX class", "NX-01", "Enterprise NX-01"],         "category": "Starship Classes",         "content": "NX-class: Earth Starfleet's first Warp 5 starship class, in service in the 2150s. Lead ship: Enterprise NX-01 launched 2151 under Captain Jonathan Archer. NX-class vessels were proto-Federation starships, sleek with two nacelles and a polarized hull (no shields). They measured ~225 meters, with a crew of 80. The NX-class achieved Warp 5 speeds, enabling humanity's first deep space explorationÓ®Å71Ó®ÇÓ®Å72Ó®Ç. Armaments included plasma cannons and spatial torpedoes (later upgraded to phase cannons and photonic torpedoes), and they had a primitive transporter (initially used only for cargo). Famous missions: Enterprise NX-01's mission (2151‚Äì2155) encountering Klingons, Andorians, Suliban, Xindi, etc., laying groundwork for the Federation. The class had limited defenses (hull plating, not full deflector shields). The NX-class design influenced later Starfleet ships (e.g., the Akira-class has a similar layout). Notable ships: NX-01 Enterprise, NX-02 Columbia. The class was retired by the 2160s as United Earth merged into the Federation and newer starship classes (like Daedalus) came into service."       },       {         "name": "Constitution-class",         "keys": ["Constitution-class", "Constitution class"],         "category": "Starship Classes",         "content": "Constitution-class: A Federation Class I heavy cruiser of the 23rd centuryÓ®Å73Ó®Ç, arguably Starfleet's most famous design. It was a long-range explorer equipped for multi-year missions. Specs: ~289 meters long, crew ~430. It featured a saucer section, secondary hull, and twin warp nacelles. Constitution-class ships (often just called \"Starship-class\" in TOS) were armed with photon torpedoes and phaser banks, and equipped with deflector shields. They were the pride of Starfleet; ships like USS Enterprise (NCC-1701) and USS Enterprise-A are this class. The original 12 ships (like USS Enterprise, Exeter, Potemkin) conducted the first five-year deep-space missions. In the 2270s, the class received a major refit (sometimes dubbed Constitution-class refit or Constitution II) with upgraded warp cores, armaments, and more modern hull designÓ®Å74Ó®Ç. The class remained in service through the late 23rd century (Enterprise-A decommissioned in 2293). Constitution-class vessels are legendary for their versatility ‚Äì capable in exploration, combat, and diplomacy. The design set the standard for future Starfleet ship aesthetics and capabilities."       },       {         "name": "Excelsior-class",         "keys": ["Excelsior-class", "Excelsior class"],         "category": "Starship Classes",         "content": "Excelsior-class: A Federation starship class commissioned in the late 23rd century and serving well into the 24th. Initially built as a prototype \"transwarp\" testbed (USS Excelsior NX-2000 \"The Great Experiment\" in 2285), it became a successful line of heavy cruisers after standard warp drive was retained. The Excelsior-class is larger than Constitution-class (approx 467m long, crew ~500) with an elongated secondary hull and flattened saucer. It was armed with photon torpedoes (including fore and aft launchers) and advanced phasers, with strong shields. After early teething issues, it proved reliable ‚Äì e.g., USS Excelsior (NCC-2000) under Captain Sulu charted gaseous anomalies (2290s). The class formed a backbone of Starfleet through the 24th century; many were still active during the Dominion War. Some variants (Enterprise-B was an Excelsior variant with added impulse bulges). The longevity of the Excelsior design (over 80 years of service) earned it the nickname \"the workhorse of Starfleet\". Notable ships: USS Excelsior, USS Enterprise-B (NCC-1701-B), USS Lakota (which received upgrades to match a Defiant-class in DS9). The Excelsior-class symbolized the transition era of Starfleet expansion."       },       {         "name": "Miranda-class",         "keys":

6.content: ["Miranda-class", "Miranda class"],         "category": "Starship Classes",         "content": "Miranda-class: A medium-sized Federation starship class first entering service in the late 23rd century. The Miranda-class (e.g., USS Reliant NCC-1864 from 2285) features a distinctive design: a saucer hull with two underslung warp nacelles and a roll-bar (weapons pod) above (in most configurations). It is sometimes called a \"light cruiser\" or frigate. Miranda-class ships are versatile ‚Äì used for survey, patrol, and support roles. They have slightly fewer weapons and slightly smaller crew than a Constitution-class (crew ~220). The class was in service for at least 111 yearsÓ®Å75Ó®Ç, with many active through the 24th century (Miranda variants seen in the Battle of Wolf 359 and the Dominion War). Notable Mirandas: USS Reliant (captured by Khan in 2285), USS Saratoga (Benjamin Sisko‚Äôs ship lost at Wolf 359). The longevity of the Miranda design attests to its solid engineering. Often the \"roll bar\" contains torpedo launchers and sensor pods. Later variants (sometimes fan-called \"Reliant-class\" refit) got upgrades but the spaceframe remained dependable. The Miranda-class was one of Starfleet‚Äôs most numerous ship types in the late TNG era, often assigned to colony defense or border duties."       },       {         "name": "Ambassador-class",         "keys": ["Ambassador-class", "Ambassador class"],         "category": "Starship Classes",         "content": "Ambassador-class: A Federation starship class introduced in the early 24th century, bridging the gap between the Excelsior and Galaxy classes. Ambassador-class ships (e.g., USS Enterprise-C NCC-1701-C) served as Starfleet‚Äôs flagships in the 2330s‚Äì2340s. They have a saucer similar to Galaxy-class but a more sloped secondary hull and proportionally smaller nacelles. The class is large (about 520m) and carries a crew around 700. Armaments include photon torpedoes and advanced phaser arrays; they were among the first to have fully integrated isolinear computer systems. USS Enterprise-C famously sacrificed itself defending the Klingon colony Narendra III from Romulan attack in 2344 ‚Äì an act that solidified the Federation-Klingon allianceÓ®Å76Ó®Ç. Ambassador-class ships were less numerous than Excelsiors or Galaxies but filled key roles in their era (e.g., USS Zhukov, USS Yamaguchi). By the late 24th century most were retired or in secondary roles, but some participated in the Dominion War. The Ambassador-class design, while short-lived as top of the line, influenced the Galaxy-class (which followed about 20 years later)."       },       {         "name": "Galaxy-class",         "keys": ["Galaxy-class", "Galaxy class"],         "category": "Starship Classes",         "content": "Galaxy-class: A Federation starship class commissioned in the 2360s as Starfleet's premier explorers. Galaxy-class ships are huge (approx 642m long, 42 decks) and carry over 1,000 crew and civilians (including families). The USS Enterprise-D (NCC-1701-D) is the most famous example. These vessels have modular designs with a separable saucer section for emergency separationÓ®Å77Ó®Ç. Galaxy-class ships have powerful warp cores (warp 9.6 cruise, up to 9.8 max), advanced shields, and extensive armaments: 12+ phaser arrays and 2-3 photon torpedo launchers. They also boast science labs, holodecks, and luxurious accommodations ‚Äì built for long-term deep space missions. The class initially had six ships (Enterprise-D, Yamato, Odyssey, Galaxy, etc.). Some were lost (USS Odyssey destroyed by Jem'Hadar in 2370). The Galaxy design proved adaptable: during the Dominion War, surviving Galaxy-class had upgrades like quantum torpedoes and enhanced shields and served as frontline battleships. After the Enterprise-D was lost in 2371 (Veridian III), the newer Sovereign-class took over flagship duty, but refit Galaxy-class ships remain in service. The Galaxy-class is a symbol of 24th-century Starfleet ‚Äì blending scientific capability and defensive power on an unprecedented scale."       },       {         "name": "Defiant-class",         "keys": ["Defiant-class", "Defiant class"],         "category": "Starship Classes",         "content": "Defiant-class: A unique Federation starship class ‚Äì officially an escort, in practice a warship ‚Äì designed in the late 2360s specifically to fight the Borg. The USS Defiant NX-74205 was the prototype, assigned to Deep Space 9. It's a small, compact ship (only 4 decks, ~120m long, crew ~50) with minimal amenities, built for combat superiority. Defiant-class ships have ablative armor and the most powerful armaments for their size: e.g., 4 pulse phaser cannons, quantum torpedo launchers, and strong shields. They are overpowered for their frame (the Defiant proto almost shook itself apart in trials). But once tweaked, the Defiant proved extremely effective, playing a key role in the Dominion War (as Sisko‚Äôs command ship). These ships lack luxuries ‚Äì no families, limited science labs ‚Äì but have a cloaking device (the Defiant used a Romulan-supplied cloak in the Gamma Quadrant). Max warp ~9.5. The Defiant-class is sometimes called a \"tough little ship\" (per Riker). They packed firepower equivalent to vessels many times their size. Several Defiant-class served by the end of the Dominion War (e.g., USS Valiant, Sao Paulo (renamed Defiant after original was lost)). This class demonstrated Starfleet's shift, during emergencies, toward dedicated combat vessels while still retaining multipurpose flexibility in peacetime."       },       {         "name": "Intrepid-class",         "keys": ["Intrepid-class", "Intrepid class"],         "category": "Starship Classes",         "content": "Intrepid-class: A Federation medium explorer introduced in the 2370s, known for advanced technology and speed. The most famous example is USS Voyager NCC-74656. Intrepid-class ships are about 344m long, crew ~150, with 15 decks. They feature a sleek, streamlined profile and variable-geometry warp nacelles (which pivot ‚Äì intended to reduce subspace stress at high warp). These ships can achieve up to warp 9.975. The class has bio-neural gel pack computers (which enhance processing by using organic neural cells). Armaments include phaser arrays and photon (later quantum) torpedoes, and they have strong deflectors and advanced sensors for scientific work. An Intrepid can land on a planet surface (Voyager demonstrated this), thanks to retractable landing gear. Voyager's 7-year journey in the Delta Quadrant proved the class's resilience ‚Äì Intrepid-class ships, despite being smaller than Galaxy-class, held their own against Borg and other threats. They carry two shuttlecraft and the special \"Aeroshuttle\" or \"Delta Flyer\" (Voyager built the latter) for auxiliary missions. Intrepid-class vessels serve as fast response explorers, and their design influenced later classes. In summary, the Intrepid-class combines science vessel capabilities with tactical strength and high agility, epitomized by Voyager's successful solo return from 70,000 light-years away."       },       {         "name": "Sovereign-class",         "keys": ["Sovereign-class", "Sovereign class"],         "category": "Starship Classes",         "content": "Sovereign-class: Starfleet's premier battleship/explorer of the late 24th century, succeeding the Galaxy-class as flagship. The first ship, USS Sovereign, launched in the 2370s, but the class is best known for USS Enterprise-E (NCC-1701-E) commissioned in 2372Ó®Å78Ó®Ç. Sovereign-class ships are about 685m long (roughly same length as Galaxy but more streamlined), with 24 decks and crew around 700. They were designed incorporating lessons from the Borg and Dominion conflicts: Sovereigns have ablative armor, high-yield shield grids, and firepower including 16+ phaser arrays and multiple torpedo launchers (fore and aft, capable of quantum torpedoes). Enterprise-E even had a forward deployable phaser cannon in the refitted version (seen in Nemesis). These ships are extremely fast (sustainable warp 9.9+). The Sovereign-class retains exploration facilities but with greater emphasis on tactical systems and a smaller civilian footprint (no families on board normally). The design is sleek with a long saucer and slim secondary hull, underslung nacelles, and a distinctive spoon-shaped deflector. Enterprise-E participated in defeating the Borg in 2373 and the Battle of Ba'ku (2375), among other missions. The Sovereign-class continues into the 25th century as a top-of-line vessel, symbolizing Starfleet's blend of might and diplomacy."       },       {         "name": "Nebula-class",         "keys": ["Nebula-class", "Nebula class"],         "category": "Starship Classes",         "content": "Nebula-class: A 24th-century Federation starship class that can be considered a sister design to the Galaxy-class. Nebula-class ships (e.g., USS Phoenix, USS Sutherland) share many components with Galaxy-class but in a more compact, mission-flexible frame. They have a triangular aft section instead of a long stardrive, and a dorsal equipment module (which can be a sensor pod, weapons pod, etc.). This makes Nebulas versatile for different mission profiles (scientific, tactical, etc.). At ~442m length, ~32 decks, Nebulas carry about 750 crew at max (usually fewer). Armament and performance are slightly less than a Galaxy (due to smaller warp core), but still formidable ‚Äì phaser arrays, torpedoes, strong shields. They introduced around the 2350s. Nebula-class ships played roles in the Dominion War (the USS Honshu, USS Bellerophon, etc.). The Nebula-class's interchangeable pod (sometimes a wide sensor array, sometimes additional torpedo launchers) is its signature feature. In appearance, a Nebula has a saucer and nacelles somewhat like a Galaxy, but with a flattened rear hull and the above-saucer pod. These ships were used for deep space research, patrol, and as support cruisers. The Nebula-class demonstrates Starfleet's approach of modular

7.content: design to adapt one spaceframe to multiple roles."       },       {         "name": "Klingon D7/K't'inga-class",         "keys": ["K't'inga-class", "D7 battlecruiser", "Klingon D7"],         "category": "Starship Classes",         "content": "D7/K't'inga-class Battlecruiser: The primary Klingon warship class of the 23rd century. The D7 class was introduced in the mid-22nd (by some accounts) to early 23rd century as a formidable cruiser. It features the iconic Klingon design: a command module head, long neck, and spread-wing engineering hull with nacelles. Armed with disruptor cannons and photon torpedoes, D7s were on par with Federation Constitution-class ships. In 2270s, the class was upgraded and dubbed K't'inga-class (e.g., ships seen in Star Trek: The Motion Picture), with improved weapons, shields, and a more detailed hull plating. K't'inga-class ships served through the late 23rd and even into the 24th century (some were used as late as the Dominion War as second-line ships). Notable usage: Chancellor Gorkon's flagship Kronos One was a K't'inga. These battlecruisers often carried about 300 crew, and had warp capability comparable to Federation ships of the era. They typically had forward torpedo launchers in the head and aft torpedoes in the stern. The D7/K't'inga silhouette became synonymous with Klingon power in TOS/TMP eras. Some variants (like Kingons shared this design with Romulans briefly during alliance in 2260s). Overall, the D7/K't'inga proved a durable, respected design that Klingons kept upgrading over decades."       },       {         "name": "Klingon Bird-of-Prey",         "keys": ["Bird-of-Prey", "Klingon Bird-of-Prey"],         "category": "Starship Classes",         "content": "Klingon Bird-of-Prey: A widely used class of small warship in the Klingon Defense Force from the 2280s through the 24th century. \"Bird-of-Prey\" actually refers to a series of vessels of varying sizes (B'rel-class scout ~90m, ~12 crew; K'Vort-class cruiser ~320m, dozens of crew) but all share the same basic design: avian-inspired hull with movable wings and a forward command pod. Birds-of-Prey are equipped with cloaking devices, making them excellent for ambush and reconnaissance. They are armed typically with disruptor cannons (wing-mounted) and photon torpedo launchers (usually fore, sometimes aft). Notably, Captain Kirk's crew commandeered a Bird-of-Prey (\"HMS Bounty\") in 2286. In TNG/DS9, Birds-of-Prey are the workhorses of Klingon fleets, valued for their maneuverability and cloaking. They can land on planets (in Star Trek: The Voyage Home one landed on Earth). The wing positions can adjust for cruising (up) or attack (down) modes. Birds-of-Prey, especially the small B'rel types, have limited defense when uncloaked (a trade-off for stealth). However, the larger variants pack a punch in numbers. Famous examples: Kruge's Bird-of-Prey (destroyed by Kirk), the Rotarran (Martok's command in DS9). They epitomize Klingon daring: strike unseen, hit hard, and fade away under cloak."       },       {         "name": "Klingon Vor'cha-class",         "keys": ["Vor'cha-class", "Vorcha-class"],         "category": "Starship Classes",         "content": "Vor'cha-class Attack Cruiser: The primary capital ship of the Klingon Empire in the late 24th century (introduced around 2367). The Vor'cha, co-designed with some Federation technical aid during the Alliance period, is a formidable warship larger than the old K't'inga. It has a blocky forward hull, elongated aft hull, and underslung warp engines. A Vor'cha is roughly 480m long, crew ~2,500. It carries disruptor arrays, photon torpedoes, and an ion cannon (seen in TNG). Chancellor Gowron's flagship was a Vor'cha (during the Klingon-Federation brief war and early Dominion War). Vor'cha-class ships have shielding and firepower comparable to Federation Galaxy-class, making them the backbone of the Klingon fleet pre-Dominion War. They have warp speeds around warp 9+. Many Vor'chas fought in Dominion War battles. Their design retains a distinct Klingon feel but with bulkier, more angular lines than earlier smooth-hulled ships. In battle, Vor'chas often lead squadrons of Birds-of-Prey. They began entering service when the Klingons still had tensions with the Federation (one first encountered in 2367 by K'mpec's emissary K'Ehleyr). The Vor'cha solidified Klingon supremacy until the even larger Negh'Var was built."       },       {         "name": "Klingon Negh'Var-class",         "keys": ["Negh'Var-class", "Neghvar"],         "category": "Starship Classes",         "content": "Negh'Var-class Warship: The largest and most powerful Klingon starship class as of the late 24th century. The Negh'Var served as the Klingon flagship from 2372 onward. First seen during the First Klingon invasion of Cardassia (DS9: \"The Way of the Warrior\"), the IKS Negh'Var was Chancellor Gowron's command ship. The Negh'Var design is massive (over 680m) and heavily armed: numerous disruptor banks, multiple torpedo launchers, and a formidable forward disruptor cannon. It has strong shielding and heavy armor. The Negh'Var has a similar basic layout to a Vor'cha but scaled up and with a bulkier forward section and additional structures along the hull. In the Dominion War, Negh'Vars led Klingon fleets (General Martok commanded the Negh'Var-class IKS Rotarran after the war, in the novels). In the Mirror Universe, Regent Worf had a Negh'Var battleship that was arguably the most powerful ship of its time. The Negh'Var-class is somewhat slow but meant as a command-and-control dreadnought. Post-war, the Klingons continue to build on the Negh'Var design for future capital ships. Essentially, the Negh'Var gave the Klingon Empire a modern dreadnought to rival or exceed Starfleet's biggest vessels of the era."       },       {         "name": "Romulan Warbird (D'deridex-class)",         "keys": ["Romulan Warbird", "D'deridex-class"],         "category": "Starship Classes",         "content": "D'deridex-class Warbird: The signature capital ship of the Romulan Star Empire in the 24th century (TNG/DS9 era). Commonly just called \"Romulan Warbird,\" this massive vessel is easily recognized by its emerald-green hull and distinctive hollow-wing design. A D'deridex-class is larger than a Galaxy-class (approx 1,040m long) and powered by an artificial quantum singularity (mini black hole) instead of a matter/antimatter warp core. Warbirds are equipped with cloaking devices, allowing them to sneak unseen. They carry powerful disruptor arrays and plasma torpedo launchers. Their wings can adjust position slightly during flight. The interior volume is enormous (some say much is empty space as part of the structure). Introduced in 2364 (TNG \"The Neutral Zone\"), D'deridex Warbirds marked the Romulans' return from isolation. They typically have crew of 1,500+. Warbirds usually operate singly (one Warbird can challenge multiple Starfleet ships). Their weakness might be slightly lower maneuverability, but cloaking compensates. They have a disruptor cannon at the beak-like head for heavy blasts. Throughout the 2360s-70s, the D'deridex was the workhorse of the Romulan fleet, including during the Dominion War (where they fought alongside the Federation and Klingons). Few Starfleet captains forget the awe of a Warbird decloaking ‚Äì it personifies Romulan strength and cunning."       },       {         "name": "Cardassian Galor-class",         "keys": ["Galor-class", "Galor class"],         "category": "Starship Classes",         "content": "Galor-class: The principal Cardassian warship of the late 24th century. A Galor-class is a medium cruiser (approx 371m long, crew ~300). It has a distinctive flattened, delta-wing hull with a raised aft section and a large forward prow. Galors are equipped with spiral-wave disruptor arrays (a main array on the \"nose\" and others along wings) and photon (sometimes plasma) torpedoes. Their combat power is slightly below a Federation Nebula or Galaxy-class, but Cardassia compensates with numbers. Galors were ubiquitous in the Cardassian fleet ‚Äì e.g., the Cardassian task force in the Dominion War included hundreds of Galors. The class has multiple \"blocks\" (upgrades); the later Galor Type-3 during the Dominion War had improved weapons. Galors served as patrol cruisers and occasionally as flagships (though the larger Keldon-class was variant/upgraded form). They lack strong aft weapon coverage (a known weakness). Max warp around 9.6. Aesthetically, their ochre hull and \"spoon\"-shaped bow recall Cardassian emblem. When the Dominion upgraded some Galors, those could challenge top-of-the-line Federation ships. After Cardassia's fall, surviving Galors formed the core of the reorganized Cardassian Defense Force. In summary, the Galor-class was the sturdy backbone of Cardassian power during conflicts with the Federation, the Maquis, and the Dominion War, though individually not a match for the largest Federation/Klingon vessels without numerical superiority."       },       {         "name": "Cardassian Keldon-class",         "keys": ["Keldon-class", "Keldon class"],         "category": "Starship Classes",         "content": "Keldon-class: A Cardassian warship variant based on the Galor design, but larger and more heavily armed. Keldon-class ships have an added \"spoon\" shaped aft module on the dorsal hull, giving them a hump-backed appearance. This module provides improved propulsion and houses additional weapon systems or cargo. The Obsidian Order (Cardassian intelligence) secretly built a fleet of Keldon-class ships (with cloaking devices) for a joint Tal Shiar/Obsidian Order strike on the Founders in 2371 (which failed, leading to the Order's decimation). A Keldon is about 10-20% larger than a Galor and carries more torpedoes. In performance, it is slightly superior to Galor-class, but still not on par with Federation capital ships one-to-one. After the Obsidian Order's demise, the regular military

8.content: presumably integrated any surviving Keldons. Only a handful were seen operationally. Essentially, consider the Keldon an \"up-gunned\" Galor used for special missions. It maintains the same overall shape and yellowish hull, just bulkier. With the fall of Cardassia, few Keldons remain. In summary, the Keldon-class is a rare but formidable Cardassian cruiser, mostly notable for its use in the ill-fated anti-Dominion strike of 2371."       },       {         "name": "Jem'Hadar Attack Ship",         "keys": ["Jem'Hadar Attack Ship", "Jem'Hadar fighter"],         "category": "Starship Classes",         "content": "Jem'Hadar Attack Ship: A small, agile warship used by the Dominion as a primary attack craft, especially in the Alpha Quadrant War. Often called \"Jem'Hadar fighters,\" they are about 95 meters long, crewed by 42 Jem'Hadar and a Vorta supervisor. These ships are sleek and beetle-like, purple-gray in color. They are equipped with polaron beam weapons (piercing many shields) and torpedo launchers, plus powerful engines (Warp 9+). Although individually not as powerful as a Federation capital ship, in swarms they are deadly. Attack Ships are also equipped with basic shields and are capable of operating in atmosphere (they landed troops on AR-558). Many Federation ships fell victim to coordinated strikes by these fighters. In large fleet battles, Attack Ships acted as the Dominion equivalent of \"frigates\" or \"destroyers\". They lack longevity in drawn-out fights ‚Äì one or two good hits can destroy a fighter, as they have no warp core (they use a matter-antimatter reactor but a smaller one). Still, their high sublight speed and maneuverability allow them to outflank bigger ships. Notably, the USS Odyssey (Galaxy-class) was rammed and destroyed by a Jem'Hadar fighter in 2367. The Attack Ship design has a \"scarab\" profile with twin impulse fins aft. They usually operate in groups under a larger battleship's command. It is the most numerous Dominion ship, essentially disposable but effective. In contrast, larger Dominion ships (battle cruisers and battleships) provide command and heavy firepower. The sheer number of Attack Ships in the war overwhelmed many Alliance defenses until tactics improved."       },       {         "name": "Ferengi D'Kora-class Marauder",         "keys": ["D'Kora-class", "Ferengi Marauder"],         "category": "Starship Classes",         "content": "D'Kora-class Marauder: The principal starship type of the Ferengi Alliance, introduced in the mid-24th century. A Marauder is a large, broad saucer-shaped vessel with a distinctive orangish hull. It is about 366m long, comparable to a Galaxy-class in length but with a different configuration and smaller crew (~250). The D'Kora is both a trading vessel and a warship when needed. It has impressive armaments for a mercantile ship: particle beam weapons (sometimes referred to as \"lasers\" by early sources, though more powerful than standard lasers) and photon torpedoes, as well as strong shields. The Marauder can also reconfigure its hull (the \"wings\" can pivot slightly in some depictions). One was first seen in 2364 (TNG \"The Last Outpost\") where it nearly matched the USS Enterprise-D until power issues. Ferengi use Marauders for commerce, piracy, or show of force when collecting debts. Each is commanded by a DaiMon (Ferengi captain) who has great latitude in business ventures. Internally, they have lavish quarters for the DaiMon and spartan ones for crew. The D'Kora can deploy a small attack shuttle called a \"Ferengi shuttlepod\" from its ventral launch bay. While not usually a match for top Federation warships, a Marauder is formidable against civilian or lightly armed targets (which Ferengi often preyed upon). The D'Kora-class remains the iconic Ferengi starship silhouette: an oval forward hull with a bifurcated tail. In DS9, some Marauders were seen operating in the Gamma Quadrant (though the Ferengi avoided the Dominion War). Overall, the D'Kora serves the Ferengi ideal of profit ‚Äì it can intimidate, defend itself, and carry huge cargo for trade."       },       {         "name": "Breen Warship",         "keys": ["Breen Warship", "Breen ship"],         "category": "Starship Classes",         "content": "Breen Warship: The main combat vessel fielded by the Breen Confederacy. Breen warships have a distinct organic shape with forward prongs and a green-blue hull. They were first encountered during the Dominion War when the Breen joined in 2375. Size is roughly that of a Federation cruiser (perhaps ~400 meters). The Breen warship's most notorious feature is its energy-dampening weapon, a specialized energy discharge that could disable the power systems of enemy ships (Federation, Romulan, and Klingon ships were rendered adrift by a single hit, until countermeasures were developed)Ó®Å79Ó®Ç. These warships also carry disruptors and torpedoes, but the \"energy dampener\" made them exceptionally dangerous. During the Battle of Chin'toka, Breen ships with this weapon turned the tide, destroying many Allied ships helplessly. Breen warships are equipped with cloaking devices (as stated by some sources, possibly obtained via the Dominion alliance). They have good shields and are fast and maneuverable. Their bridge and systems accommodate Breen environmental needs (very cold). After the war, little is known; presumably the Breen kept these ships within their territory. Design-wise, Federation analysts noted Breen ships did not match known Alpha Quadrant design trends, hinting at a largely independent tech development. In summary, the Breen warship became infamous in 2375 as a \"ship killer\" until Starfleet adjusted shield modulations. It ensured the Breen a feared reputation as Dominion allies. Though fewer in number, Breen ships effectively required new tactics to confront."       },       {         "name": "Section 31",         "keys": ["Section 31"],         "category": "Organizations",         "content": "Section 31: A clandestine and autonomous intelligence organization within the Federation (though officially unacknowledged and illegal). It was established under Article 14, Section 31 of the Starfleet Charter (a clause allowing \"extraordinary measures\" in times of dire threat)Ó®Å80Ó®Ç. Section 31 operates independently, without oversight by Starfleet or the Federation governmentÓ®Å81Ó®Ç. Its agents undertake covert ops including espionage, political manipulation, sabotage, and assassination ‚Äì all to \"protect\" the Federation by any means necessary. Known history: It existed as early as the 2150s (in ENT, Agent Harris recruited Malcolm Reed), was active in the 23rd (as seen in DIS with Control and Georgiou), and in the 24th century it tried to genocide the Founders with a morphogenic virus during the Dominion War. Key agent: Luther Sloan, who attempted to recruit Dr. Bashir (DS9). Section 31 has advanced tech and uses its own discretion. While its existence is condemned by Federation ideals, its agents believe their ruthless actions keep the Federation safe in the shadowsÓ®Å82Ó®Ç. There is no formal structure known ‚Äì agents infiltrate Starfleet at high levels. Post-Dominion War, there were attempts to reform or expose Section 31. However, it is resilient and remains in the gray ‚Äì \"Officially, it doesn't exist.\""       },       {         "name": "Tal Shiar",         "keys": ["Tal Shiar"],         "category": "Organizations",         "content": "Tal Shiar: The Romulan intelligence agency, described by the Federation as the Romulan secret policeÓ®Å83Ó®Ç. They are ruthless and efficient, instilling fear both among enemies and Romulan citizens. The Tal Shiar conducts surveillance, infiltration, interrogation, and elimination of threats to the Romulan Star Empire. They operate with virtually unlimited authority ‚Äì even Romulan military commanders fear the Tal Shiar's scrutiny. Notably, in 2371 the Tal Shiar joined Cardassia's Obsidian Order in an ill-fated assault on the Founders; their combined fleet was destroyed in the Omarion Nebula, crippling both agencies. The Tal Shiar was led by Chairman Koval in the late 2370s (secretly a Federation mole per novels). Methods include brutal interrogations (often using mind probes), kidnappings, and the use of undercover operatives (e.g., Colonel Lovok turned out to be a Changeling during the joint attack). Even after the fall of Romulus (2387), the Tal Shiar survived, influencing the Romulan Free State and later the Terran Empire (as seen in PIC with the Zhat Vash, an offshoot of Tal Shiar). In short, the Tal Shiar is synonymous with Romulan state security ‚Äì utterly loyal to the Empire, utterly unforgiving. \"Rumors of Tal Shiar\" are enough to keep populations in line through fear."       },       {         "name": "Obsidian Order",         "keys": ["Obsidian Order"],         "category": "Organizations",         "content": "Obsidian Order: The primary intelligence agency of the Cardassian Union. One of the most ruthless and efficient organizations in the quadrantÓ®Å84Ó®Ç, it functioned as Cardassia's secret police. The Order operated independently of the military (Central Command), often with better resources and no legal restraints. Its agents had a reputation for total information awareness ‚Äì \"The Order knows you committed a crime before you do.\" The Obsidian Order forbade its operatives from having families (to prevent leverage against them). They conducted extreme interrogations and surveillance; citizens simply \"disappeared\" if suspected of disloyalty. In 2371, under Chairman Enabran Tain, the Order built a secret fleet of cloaked Keldon-class ships (violating treaties) to attack the Founders. It was a trap; the fleet was destroyed, and most Obsidian Order agents were killed, effectively dismantling the Order. During the Dominion occupation of Cardassia, the Order was already gone, which made the Dominion's takeover easier (no internal security resistance). Post-Dominion War, some surviving former Order agents

9.content: (like Garak) took roles in rebuilding Cardassia. The Obsidian Order's legacy is one of fear ‚Äì the mere mention that an agent might be watching ensured Cardassians' loyalty. In DS9 \"Second Skin,\" it was revealed the Order sometimes ran long cons (e.g., planting a spy by altering their identity). The Order and Tal Shiar often paralleled each other; both were taken down by the Dominion. In sum, the Obsidian Order was the shadowy blade of Cardassia's totalitarian regime ‚Äì extremely effective until its bold overreach led to ruin."       },       {         "name": "Orion Syndicate",         "keys": ["Orion Syndicate"],         "category": "Organizations",         "content": "Orion Syndicate: An organized crime network operating across multiple quadrants, prominently involving Orion individuals but also members of other species. The Syndicate deals in a broad range of illicit activities: piracy, smuggling, slave trade, extortion, assassination-for-hire, racketeering, and espionage. It is decentralized, consisting of various crime bosses and cartels (often referred by region or specialty)Ó®Å85Ó®Ç. They maintain a veil of secrecy; members often communicate via dead drops and shadow markets. Even in the Federation, the Syndicate has corrupt tentacles ‚Äì as shown in DS9 where Chief O'Brien went undercover to expose them and found Starfleet informants compromised. Typical Orion Syndicate operations might include: running illegal dilithium mines, smuggling banned substances (like Felicium), or providing hitmen. They also were implied to have influence on Frontier colonies (Rigel X, etc.). Orion women sometimes serve as intermediaries (using their pheromones to manipulate targets), but leadership can be of any species ‚Äì e.g., a known boss was a Nausicaan named Raimus. The Syndicate was a nuisance to Starfleet Intelligence for years; a big sting in 2374 (DS9 ‚ÄúHonor Among Thieves‚Äù) disrupted some cell, but the Syndicate endured. In the 23rd century, an Orion Syndicate existed but may have been more disorganized (the term used loosely for Orion pirate bands). By the 24th, it became a more structured cross-species mafia. The Dominion War provided opportunities (black market weapons, Ketracel-White deals). Post-war, the Syndicate likely persisted in poorer sectors. Essentially, the Orion Syndicate fills the role of the galaxy‚Äôs criminal underworld ‚Äì when there's a lucrative illegal deal, chances are the Syndicate has a hand in it."       },       {         "name": "Prime Directive",         "keys": ["Prime Directive", "General Order 1"],         "category": "Principles",         "content": "Prime Directive (General Order 1): Starfleet's foremost guiding principle of non-interference in the natural development of alien civilizationsÓ®Å86Ó®Ç. It prohibits Starfleet personnel from revealing themselves or otherwise intervening in the affairs of pre-warp societies, and from interfering in the internal political or social processes of any society, even if such interference is well-intentioned. The Prime Directive is meant to prevent cultural contamination and imperialism. It applies especially to civilizations that have not achieved interstellar flight (pre-warp). Violations have occurred in extreme circumstances (Kirk & Picard each bent or broke it to save lives or correct prior interference). Officially, saving a starship crew or Federation lives does not trump the Prime Directive (in practice, captains weigh the moral dilemma). The Prime Directive has been cited to allow entire civilizations to die (TNG: \"Pen Pals\" or \"Homeward\") rather than interfere. It's both ethical backbone and burden for Starfleet officers. The Directive also has extensions about not interfering in power struggles of warp societies (e.g., not picking sides in a civil war). The philosophy behind it is that every society has the right to evolve on its own, and Starfleet isn't an imperial arm. In-universe, when broken, consequences can be dire (like in TOS \"A Private Little War\" when Kirk arms villagers to balance Klingon interference). Later series mention over 47 sub-orders clarifying situations. In sum: the Prime Directive places non-interference above all else ‚Äì \"No starship may interfere with the normal development of any alien life or society.\""       },       {         "name": "Temporal Prime Directive",         "keys": ["Temporal Prime Directive"],         "category": "Principles",         "content": "Temporal Prime Directive: A Federation principle analogous to the Prime Directive but regarding time travel. It mandates that Starfleet personnel should not interfere with the timeline or historical events. This means if someone travels through time (accidentally or deliberately), they must make every effort to minimize impact and to restore the original timeline if changes occur. All temporal technology or events are tightly controlled by the Federation Department of Temporal Investigations in the 29th century. Even conversations about future knowledge are restricted (for example, crew of USS Voyager, after returning from the Delta Quadrant, were debriefed under temporal protocols regarding future info). Violations of the Temporal Prime Directive are considered extremely serious, as they could erase or alter entire timelines. For instance, Captain Janeway expressed commitment to it but did violate it in the Voyager finale to ensure her crew's survival. The concept was referenced as early as the 24th century ‚Äì in TNG and Voyager. Essentially, the Temporal Prime Directive forbids using time travel for personal or political gain and requires Federation officers to preserve historical integrityÓ®Å87Ó®Ç. A related notion is the \"Temporal Integrity Commission\" (seen in novels) which monitors time. In short, it is \"non-interference\" applied to time: do not change history, even if you think it will improve things (as the consequences can be unpredictable and catastrophic)."       },       {         "name": "Stardate System",         "keys": ["stardate", "stardates"],         "category": "Reference",         "content": "Stardate: The dating system used by Starfleet for log entries. In TOS (2260s), stardates were essentially arbitrary numbers chosen by writers (roughly advancing through the series)Ó®Å88Ó®Ç. By TNG era, a more defined system exists: A TNG stardate is a five-digit number and decimal. The first digit \"4\" indicates 24th century (\"4\" for 24XXs)Ó®Å89Ó®Ç. The second digit corresponds to the TV season (e.g., \"41xxx.x\" is season 1 of TNG set in 2364, \"42xxx.x\" season 2 in 2365, etc.)Ó®Å90Ó®Ç. The remaining three digits progress within a season (000 to 999 roughly), and the decimal represents a fraction of a day. For example, Stardate 43989.1 is late in TNG season 3 (2366). The conversion isn't exact to real dates, but roughly 1000 stardate units ~ 1 year. DS9 and Voyager continued TNG's numbering (VOY started ~48300 since set in 2371). TOS-era stardates (e.g., 1512.2) were deliberately inconsistent to avoid pinning down exact years ‚Äì though later sources put TOS stardates around 2265-2269. The reboot (Kelvin) films used stardates as simply the Earth year followed by point and day of year (e.g., stardate 2258.42 ~ February 11, 2258)Ó®Å91Ó®Ç. In-universe, some explanations say stardate varies by location and warp (but that isn't canonical). The official stance: stardates are a timekeeping system that, by the 24th century, at least increment consistently with time. A fun note: in TOS, the animated series even had wildly out-of-order stardates. Fans and novelists have tried to rationalize historical stardates ‚Äì for practical use, the TNG scheme is accepted as standard for the modern era. So a captain's log in 2375 might be stardate 52xxx.x (as seen in DS9)."       },       {         "name": "Warp Factor Scale",         "keys": ["warp factor", "warp speed", "Warp 9", "warp 10"],         "category": "Reference",         "content": "Warp Factors: The warp scale is the measurement of faster-than-light velocity used by Federation and others. In the 22nd-23rd century (TOS era), warp factor was defined by a geometric progression where speed in terms of c (speed of light) was roughly the cube of the warp factorÓ®Å92Ó®ÇÓ®Å93Ó®Ç (e.g., Warp 2 ‚âà 8c, Warp 3 ‚âà 27c, etc.; Warp 6 ~ 216cÓ®Å94Ó®Ç). By the mid-23rd, Warp 6 was standard cruise, Warp 8 was high emergency speed, and Warp 10 was theoretical infinite speed (some TOS episodes violated this with warp 14, etc., but later continuity adjusted the scale). In 24th century (TNG), the warp scale was recalibrated so that Warp 10 is an asymptote of infinite speed ‚Äì unreachableÓ®Å95Ó®ÇÓ®Å96Ó®Ç. The formula up to warp 9 was adjusted (warp factors 1-9 correspond to an exponential increase, where Warp 9 ~ 1516c, and as you approach Warp 10, speed grows toward infinity)Ó®Å97Ó®Ç. Thus Warp 9.6 is extremely fast, and beyond 9.9 each increment is huge (Voyager once hit 9.975). The term \"Warp factor\" essentially is an index on a scale; it isn't linear. The Federation also recognized that sustained high warp can damage subspace (leading to warp speed limits in some regions). Practical reference: Warp 1 = 1c (speed of light)Ó®Å98Ó®Ç; Warp 5 (ENT era max) ~ 200c; Warp 9 ~ 1500c. Above Warp 9, starships use terms like 9.2, 9.6 etc. Transwarp or quantum slipstream are separate schemes beyond the standard scale. Also notable: different species have different warp efficiencies (e.g., a Borg cube at warp 9 is faster than a Galaxy-class at warp 9 in some depictions). But generally, warp factor gives a rough idea of travel time: e.g., 1 ly at Warp 1 = 1 year; at Warp 9 ~ 2.5 days. In short, warp factors provide a convenient scale for FTL travel, with the understanding that Warp 10 is an unattainable infinite speed barrierÓ®Å99Ó®Ç."       },       {         "name": "Starship Registries & Prefixes",         "keys": ["NCC", "USS", "registry", "prefix", "NX-"],         "category": "Reference",         "content": "Starship Registries & Prefixes: Starfleet starships carry registry numbers

10.content: typically prefixed with \"USS\" (United Star Ship) and \"NCC\" on their hullsÓ®Å100Ó®Ç. \"NCC\" has no confirmed meaning in canon (possibly derived from naval registration conventions) but is used for most Federation vessels (e.g., NCC-1701 for USS Enterprise)Ó®Å101Ó®Ç. Experimental or prototype Starfleet ships often used the prefix \"NX\" (e.g., NX-2000 Excelsior prototype, NX-class starships like NX-01)Ó®Å102Ó®Ç. In the 22nd century, Earth Starfleet used \"NX\" for their first warp 5 ships and \"NV\" or others for earlier craft. Other cultures: Klingon Defense Force vessels in English often get prefix \"IKS\" (Imperial Klingon Ship) in translationsÓ®Å103Ó®Ç. Romulan warships are sometimes given \"IRW\" (Imperial Romulan Warbird) in literatureÓ®Å104Ó®Ç ‚Äì notably the computer display in TNG \"Face of the Enemy\" showed IRW Khazara. Cardassian ships in some sources use \"CDS\" (Cardassian Defense Ship)Ó®Å105Ó®Ç, though this wasn't seen on-screen. Similarly, Ferengi vessels are sometimes labeled \"FMS\" (Ferengi Merchant Ship) in reference works (non-canon)Ó®Å106Ó®Ç. The Mirror Universe Terran Empire ships used \"ISS\" (Imperial Star Ship) as prefix (e.g., ISS Enterprise)Ó®Å107Ó®Ç. In Starfleet, registries are unique numeric identifiers; when a ship is decommissioned, sometimes its number is retired (except for legacy like Enterprises with letter suffixes). Federation civilian or merchant vessels might use \"SS\" (Space Ship or Star Ship) or \"MV\" (Merchant Vessel) as prefix. Bajoran militia vessels used \"USS\" once integrated into Starfleet, but during independence might just use name and registry. In summary, prefix conventions: USS (Federation), IKS (Klingon)Ó®Å108Ó®Ç, IRW (Romulan)Ó®Å109Ó®Ç, etc., while registry numbers like NCC-XXXX are mostly Federation practice. Other powers mostly don't display such numbers openly (Klingon and Romulan hulls often just have emblems). These prefixes and registries help identify origin and class of starships across the galaxy."       },       {         "name": "Dominion War",         "keys": ["Dominion War"],         "category": "Historical Events",         "content": "Dominion War (2373-2375): A major interstellar conflict fought from 2373 to 2375, though related conflicts began earlier. The war involved all major powers of the Alpha Quadrant ‚Äì primarily the Federation, Klingon Empire, and later Romulan Star Empire ‚Äì against the Dominion (from the Gamma Quadrant) allied with the Cardassian Union (and later the Breen Confederacy)Ó®Å110Ó®Ç. It was one of the bloodiest wars in galactic history. Key events: The Dominion formed an alliance with a dissatisfied Cardassia (Dukat‚Äôs coup in late 2372), immediately leading to war. Early in the war, the Dominion captured Deep Space Nine and blockaded the wormhole (Operation Return in 2374 liberated DS9)Ó®Å111Ó®Ç. The entry of the Romulans into the Alliance in mid-2374 (prompted by a forged hologram and Senator Vreenak‚Äôs assassination) helped turn tidesÓ®Å112Ó®Ç. In 2375 the Breen joined the Dominion, launching a devastating attack on Starfleet Headquarters and deploying an energy-dampening weapon that neutralized Allied ships in battleÓ®Å113Ó®Ç. Nonetheless, the Allies fought back. The war‚Äôs final offensive, Operation: Dominion (Battle of Cardassia, late 2375), saw the Alliance push to Cardassia Prime. Legate Damar led a Cardassian rebellion that disabled Dominion‚Äôs planetary defenses. In retaliation, the Female Changeling ordered the extermination of Cardassian populations (killing 800 million). Facing defeat, the Founder eventually surrendered to Captain Sisko (after Odo linked with her and offered a cure for the morphogenic virus). The Treaty of Bajor officially ended the warÓ®Å114Ó®Ç. The cost: Over 2 million Federation casualties, thousands of ships lost. Klingon Empire‚Äôs fleet was gutted. Cardassia lay in ruins. The Dominion retreated to the Gamma Quadrant. The war‚Äôs outcome redefined Alpha Quadrant politics, ushering in an era of cooperation (e.g., Federation-Klingon-Romulan d√©tente). The Dominion War is remembered as a test of the Federation‚Äôs values and unity under fire ‚Äì and the closest the Federation ever came to annihilation."       },       {         "name": "Battle of Wolf 359",         "keys": ["Wolf 359", "Battle of Wolf 359"],         "category": "Historical Events",         "content": "Battle of Wolf 359 (2367): A pivotal and tragic battle between Starfleet and the Borg Collective. A single Borg cube under the control of Locutus (the assimilated Captain Picard) engaged a task force of 40 Starfleet ships near the Wolf 359 system, 8 light years from Earth. The cube effortlessly defeated the fleet ‚Äì 39 Federation ships were destroyedÓ®Å115Ó®Ç and over 11,000 Starfleet personnel were killed or assimilatedÓ®Å116Ó®Ç. Notable ships lost: USS Saratoga (Cmdr. Sisko's ship, his wife Jennifer killed in action), USS Melbourne, USS Kyushu, USS Endeavor, among others. The battle delayed the Borg for a short time but at horrific cost. The Borg cube then proceeded to Earth. It was ultimately stopped in Earth orbit by the crew of the Enterprise-D (who rescued Picard and used his link to the Borg to issue a shutdown command). The aftermath of Wolf 359 had a profound effect: Starfleet accelerated projects like the Defiant-class starship (a \"Borg killer\" warship), improved tactical training (Red Squad exercises), and formed strategies for future Borg encounters. Culturally, Wolf 359 was a national tragedy ‚Äì memorials were built for the lost. Benjamin Sisko, who survived, was left emotionally scarred (blaming Picard for a time). The battle demonstrated the terrifying power of a single Borg vessel and forced the Federation to realize the Borg threat would require new ways of thinking. Wolf 359 remains one of Starfleet‚Äôs darkest hours, frequently referenced as a benchmark for destructive potential (even 20 years later, officers speak of it in hushed tones)."       }     ]   } }
